title: Parents share heartbreaking moment tot ravaged by meningitis dies in their arms
text:
CATERS WORST NIGHTMARE: Little Harry died from meningitis just one day after he was diagnosed 
Little Harry’s body was swollen and covered in a deep purple rash when he died just one day after being diagnosed. 
His devastated parents Louise and John Done are still coming to terms with his death after they initally thought their little one was just suffering with a common cold. 
They were forced to make the painful decision to turn off Harry’s life support after medics told them the terrible infection had left him brain damaged. 
CATERS HAPPY: Harry was described as a cheeky and content little boy “It was my worst nightmare come true” Louise Done 
And now the brave parents have shared photos of Harry in their arms, his body swollen until “unrecognisable” after parts of his hands, fingers, feet and legs turned black with blood poisoning. 
Moments later he was dead — but now the couple hope the shocking image will raise awareness of the disease so no other parents have to go through the heartbreak that they did. 
Louise, from Bolton, in Greater Manchester, said: "The reason we released the pictures is because people don't realise how brutal meningitis can be. 
"Meningitis ravages them before your eyes. It's unbelievable what it does. It eats you away. 
CATERS HEARTBREAKING: Harry died just moments after this photo was taken 
"It was my worst nightmare come true. It feels like I've been in a parallel world after his death. Your whole perception on life changes." 
The couple got a call from John’s daughter in February, 2015, saying Harry wasn’t well and they should return home. 
As soon as they saw Harry they rang for an ambulance, and Louise said she had a gut feeling something was seriously wrong. 
CATERS HORROR: Medics told his devastated parents he was brain dead 
As the rash began to spread over his body medics told the terrified parents that they needed to put Harry to sleep. 
“I knew he wouldn't wake up, he was looking in my eyes and I told him I would be here when he wakes up,” Louise said. 
The parents' worst fears were confirmed when doctors told them his brain had swollen and he was brain dead. 
Since Harry’s death, Louise has been raising awareness of the importance of getting babies vaccinated against Meningitis B. 
CATERS ADORABLE: Harry's parents have campaigned for all children to be vaccinated 
From September 2015 this vaccination was included in the childhood immunisation programme for children born on or after July 2015 — after Harry's death. 
Louise added: “Harry was such a happy boy. He was cheeky and smiley. 
“He would always be laughing and smiling. He was such a happy and content little boy.” Related articles
